feedback: It did not feel particularly useful because the composition of chips was never specified, so I could not judge whether or not there was a likelihood of it being the truth or a lie.

I didn't pay any attention to it. I thought it could be misleading and makes you think that you knew more information than you did and the best method was to just ignore it, especially as you didn't know the composition of the bag of chips.

It was tricky and definitely played with my decision, but knowing it may have been not true made me stick to my original decision/gut feeling more. I think it wasn't useful in the sense that it made you second-guess yourself, but it definitely did give me something to think about, even though it may have not been true.
No
It was not useful, and did not affect my answer.

The information was never useful because I did not know the composition of the chips in the bag determining whether it was a truth or a lie. If I had known the odds of it being a lie or truth I would have bet differently.
it did not seem helpful; it made me question the computer's description of the color drawn, and I therefore could not use this information in my answer
Because it was nearly impossible to determine whether the ball drawn was the color as stated without knowing which chip was drawn, I feel it had very little impact on my final answer.
this information did not affect my answer because I did not know the probability of it being a truth or lie
It was not useful and did not affect my answer.
Not useful at all
did not receive info
It did not affect my answer because I didn't know if it was trustworthy.
I decided that I would not consider this information and pretend like there was just a ball chosen. It helped me think more clearly about what to choose
It did not affect my answer at all. There was no way of knowing if it was the truth or a lie.
It did. The drawing of the chip would tell me info about my odds of success

That information was useful because if it was true, then it was the correct answer and if it was false it was not. I think that if there had been more than two options then the information may have not been useful. It did affect my answer.
There was not enough information to really tell if the color was a truth or a lie so I usually just trusted the draw instead of overthinking it.
Did not affect my answer, felt like more of a hindrance/noise in decision-making process
Information was not useful
No effect
I never received this information, it was always unknown
no, not really
Since from my perspective the probability of a lie or a truth was the same, this information was meaningless. It did not impact my decision at all.
I don't think it was useful, because it could have been a lie or a truth. I think it didn't influence my answers that much.
Knowing that the information was either true or a lie, it had no bearing on my decision to bet or not.
No it wasn't useful because I didn't know if it was true or false.
It was completely useless because I had no information about the distribution of chips. It didn't affect my answer at all.

I found that this information was not helpful as I did not know the composition of colored chips in the bag, so I would never get a good sense of whether the information provided to me by the computer was a truth or a lie. It did not affect my answer in the end and I assumed a fifty percent chance of either it being a truth or lie since I had no credible information to go off of.
Not useful at all
I tended to ignore this information and proceed as I would have if I had no information
I assumed that unknown probabilities were 50%
The information was useful to tell me where the likelihood of balls drawn was, which affected me by betting on the color that was most likely to be drawn.
Didn't feel like any information I received was helpful.

It didn't affect my answer. It wasn't useful to me because I don't know if the computer was lying or not. It seemed like the composition was still 50-50 so I made choices based on that information, and didn't use the chip information at all.
i think i was confused
The information was not useful and did not influence my answer

I didn't find the information useful. If anything, it was a distraction. I thought about it a little, but it really didn't affect my decision. I cared more about the distribution of the colors of balls in the jar. i couldn't trust the truth lie info
It did not affect my answer.

It affected my answer a little bit (like I would decide if the computer was telling me the truth or lying) and then I would use that decision to either raise (telling the truth) or lower (telling a lie) but that's about it
It did not affect my answer as I knew that I could not trust the computer
No, because we don't know the composition of this bag, so as far as I'm concerned it doesn't matter. I have no idea whether it is truth or a lie. I just ignored it when I was betting.
It did not really affect my answer, I went with the safest bets because the additional payoff was so heavily determined by random luck at the end from so many rows.
The information was not useful and did not affect my answer.
not helpful bc you still have to guess what color the ball is
I thought it was not useful. Toward the end I began to think that it might benefit me to assume it was true since I had no other info but overall not useful.
Information is completely useless. It didn't affect my choice.
it was not useful and did not affect my answer

Since the bag of chips was always of unknown composition, I really had no idea of whether the information was the truth or a lie. I did not really use the ball draw information because I didn't know if it was true and even if it was true the bag of balls always had an unknown or 50-50 composition. I did not feel confident at all in betting on the balls drawn from the bag given so little information and reason to feel like I could bet on a certain color to be chosen. This affected my answers, as I did not value receiving more information and I preferred to get the certain money rather than make the bet.

It wasn't useful! Because I don't know about the underlying distribution, my best guess is that the true percentage of red chips (for example) is distributed ~u[0,1]. This isn't super helpful because that means that in expectation, any revealed information about the draw has only a 50/50 chance of being right. I made a mistake in one of the questions because I said I'd give up $.5 for information. I thought this would mean I would get to see the true underlying distribution. Fortunately that question wasn't chosen for my payoffs
It was not useful. It did not affect my answer. I was also a bit confused on what the questions were offering during the experiment. I understand now though..
the information provided did not really ever help how much I knew about the actual choice, so i tried to be consistent
Not really
It did not affect my answer and I completely ignored it because it was useless.
Although I chose to reduce my winnings to gain information. Looking back it didn't actually effect my answer because the number of each color of balls and chips were unknown.

The information had no use to me, as there was no way of telling or even predicting if it was truth or a lie (since we didn't know the composition of the bag with the chips). As such, I considered it useless information and did not take it into consideration, it did not affect my answer.
I ignored the information since i felt it had equal chance of being right or wrong
I didn't always rely on that information because it could have been equally likely to be a lie so it didn't really affect my answer
It was only affecting my answer when the compositions of the balls was 50:50. Not useful otherwise.
It did not affect my answers, because if I didn't know the distribution of red and green chips I could not determine the likelihood of whether the computer was lying or not.
I just ignored the information because I had no way of knowing whether it was true or not.
The information did not effect my answer at all

Because the true state of the information was not known, I did not let it affect my answer to a high degree because of this uncertainty. I did not think it was very useful, but that may be a flaw in my logic.
It just complicated things and mad me feel more insecure in my answer.
It was not useful towards my decision because I could not attribute any probability to it.
No
It made me second guess a lot of choices

I felt the information about the chip drawn was too ambiguous to be helpful. After the first choice between information or no information, I realized I would rather just have no information than have the information and lose money.
I feel like because all of this was simulated and not occurring in real time I trusted the information less and would typically go with the opposite color.
Affected my answer in the sense that I was more impartial to the bag of balls in the first place.
The information given made me more apprehensive about making a riskier bet

Since it is random I do not think the information was useful. However, I selected the information that would most likely maximize my $ gain. Even though it could have been a lie, I think it affected my answer a little bit because I selected values closer to the $7 dollar range sometimes.
I do not believe it helped my decision because I did not know whether it was true or not.  Therefore, it was useless.
Not useful
I usually trusted the information given to me by the computer
No, it didn't affect my answer as it is all just a game of luck anyways.
I mostly disregarded it since I didn't know anything about the chip proportion - swayed by a few cents here or there
I didn't really alter my behavior based on the information
I didn't feel like the information was useful. It did not affect my answer. I would bet on the ball of the color that is shown, but I would not change my payout based off of the information.

I did not feel that this information was useful and it did not affect my answer because I did not know the composition of the 100 chips. If the composition of the chips was known AND not 50/50, then the information would've affected my answer.
not useful

I don't think the information on the chips was necessarily helpful. I often considered the composition of the bag and decided how I wanted to pit the possible winnings against each other. If the composition was unknown I merely considered the what I thought was guaranteed money or not based on a right/left column selection. The chip drawn information was not very useful in my thought process.
It was not useful and did not affect my answer. I felt that I could not trust it and it didn't offer anything helpul
The information was useless because the probability of the chips is unknown. It's equally likely to be a lie as a truth. I never picked information at the cost of winnings.
It didn't seem like useful information therefore I was more inclined to take a paid amount rather than guess.
Completely useless - didn't affect my decisions at all
It did not affect my answer
The information was not useful. Preference was based on trade-off of values I could win more than anything.
It did not affect my answer nor was useful because I did not know whether it was a truth or a lie. Therefore I had no new information to help make my decision, and therefore my answer stayed the same

I feel like the information provided was not useful at all, and was not influential in my answer. Because I had no way of knowing whether or not that information was true or not, nor the odds that it was true, I did not find it useful.
The information was not useful. It did not affect my answer because I had no way of knowing how likely the information was to be true.
